chapter.title: 32 Mycobacterium: Laboratory Characteristics of Slowly Growing Mycobacteria Other than Mycobacterium tuberculosis

sect1.title: 32 Mycobacterium: Laboratory Characteristics of Slowly Growing Mycobacteria Other than Mycobacterium tuberculosis

para.phrase: ADAM J. CAULFIELD, ELVIRA RICHTER, BARBARA A. BROWN-ELLIOTT, AND NANCY L. WENGENACK

sect1.para: This chapter describes the clinically significant, slowly growing nontuberculous mycobacteria (SGM). The SGM group contains a number of important human pathogens, including, but not limited to,Mycobacterium avium complex, M. kansasii complex, M. haemophilum, and M. marinum. M. tuberculosis complex (MTBC) also consists of a number of slowly growing mycobacterial species and has significant implications for clinical microbiology and public health laboratories. Therefore, chapter 31 of this Manual is dedicated to MTBC, and the MTBC is not discussed in this chapter.

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: As Tortoli noted in 2003, mycobacterial taxonomy can be divided into two major periods, defined by methods used for identification to species level (1). The first period, characterized by utilization of phenotypic studies, lasted from the late 1880s to the end of the 1980s. The second major era, characterized by a shift to genotypic studies, began during the last decade of the 20th century and has continued to the present time. A reclassification of Mycobacterium into five distinct genera has been suggested; however, this nomenclature has not become widely adopted, and retaining the single genus Mycobacterium has been recently proposed (2–5).

Of the approximately 190 currently validated species of nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM), roughly half are slowly growing species (Table 1) (6). The most clinically significant SGM species include Mycobacterium avium, M. intracellulare, M. kansasii, M. marinum, M. xenopi, M. malmoense, M. haemophilum, and M. ulcerans. M. gordonae, although rarely a pathogen, occurs frequently in human samples, usually as a consequence of contamination from tap water.

Like the rapidly growingMycobacterium (RGM) species (see chapter 33), the majority of SGM species have been described since the early 1990s with the advent of molecular technology. Members of the Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) are the SGM species most frequently isolated from clinical specimens. This complex is composed of nine individual species, which include M. avium, M. intracellulare, M. arosiense, M. colombiense, M. vulneris, M. marseillense, M. bouchedurhonense, M. timonense, and M. paraintracellulare. Additionally, four subspecies of M. avium and three subspecies of M. intracellulare have been described, which include M. avium subsp. avium, M. avium subsp. paratuberculosis, M. avium subsp. silvaticum, the nonvalidated subspecies “M. avium subsp. hominissuis,” M. intracellulare subsp. chimaera, M. intracellulare subsp. intracellulare, and M. intracellulare subsp. yongonense (7).

ForM. kansasii, seven subtypes had been described based on genetic differences (16S, hsp65, and ITS). Recently, several publications led to a reclassification proposing the elevation of these subtypes to species level with the following known or new species: M. kansasii (former subtype I), M. persicum (former subtype II), M. pseudokansasii (former subtype III), “M. ostraviense” (not validly published to date; former subtype IV), M. innocens (former subtype V), and M. attenuatum (former subtype VI) (8). The distribution and pathogenicity of subtype VII remain unclear. M. kansasii (former subtype I) is the most frequently isolated subtype/species worldwide, whereas the remaining subtypes/species are rarely isolated and have variable pathogenicity. Identification of the new species requires sequence analysis, whereas rapid molecular tests typically performed in diagnostic laboratories are often unable to differentiate between the species. The AccuProbe assay (Hologic, Marlborough, MA) for M. kansasii is positive with M. kansasii, M. persicum, M. pseudokansasii, and “M. ostraviense” but not M. attenuatum (the reactivity with M. innocens is unclear) (9). The line probe assay Genotype Mycobacteria CM (Bruker-Hain Lifescience, Nehren, Germany) recognizes M. kansasii, M. persicum, M. pseudokansasii, and M. innocens but not M. attenuatum (the reactivity with “M. ostraviense” is unclear) (10). For diagnostic purposes, we propose to use the term “M. kansasii complex” unless detailed sequence analyses have been performed.

From 2010 to 2021, approximately 25 new SGM species isolated from human clinical specimens were described. Since the last edition of thisManual, eight SGM species isolated from human specimens were officially recognized, including M. attenuatum (8), M. basiliense (11), M. decipiens (12), M. helveticum (13), M. innocens (8), M. pseudokansasii (8), M. shigaense (14), and M. vicinigordonae (15). Additionally, M. chimaera and M. yongonense have been reclassified as subspecies of M. intracellulare (7).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: UnlikeM. tuberculosis, for which humans are the definitive host and only natural reservoir, most species of NTM are widely distributed in the environment. Host risk factors for the development of SGM lung disease include age, body weight, the presence of chronic lung diseases (such as cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), alterations of chest structure, and other conditions, along with environmental exposure. Organisms can be found in samples of soil and water, including both natural and treated water sources. For example, M. avium, M. kansasii, M. lentiflavum, M. simiae, and M. xenopi are regularly recovered from municipal water and only rarely from other environmental sources.

Furthermore, unlike MTBC, there has been no evidence of animal-to-human or human-to-human transmission of SGM, with the exception ofM. marinum from fish and fish tanks. Human disease due to SGM is assumed to be acquired from environmental sources, either directly, by inhaling organisms in aerosols or traumatic implantation, or indirectly, by ingesting contaminated food or water. The source of infection may not always be determined for SGM (16).

Incidence rates of NTM disease are only estimates, since, unlike tuberculosis (TB), NTM disease is not communicable from human to human, and therefore, NTM infections are generally not required to be reported to public health agencies. Several studies representing geographically diverse countries have reported increased prevalence of NTM pulmonary infections over the past several decades. A population-based study examined the prevalence of NTM lung disease in the United States from 2008 to 2015 among members of a national health care plan with 27 million members (17). During the study period, the prevalence increased from 6.8 to 11.7 per 100,000 people, representing an average annual increase of 7.5%. Changes in the prevalence of NTM infection were most pronounced for women, with an increase from 9.6 to 16.8 per 100,000 people and for those aged 65 and older with an increase from 30.3 to 47.5 per 100,000 people. An aging population with risk factors for lung infection, increasing environmental exposure, and improvements in surveillance and laboratory identification methods may contribute to these observed increases in NTM disease.

The most common infections caused by SGM are pulmonary diseases, but skin and soft tissue, lymphatic, and disseminated infections also occur. Disseminated infections most often occur in the setting of advanced human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) disease, but non-HIV-infected patients can also be affected. Although regional variations in species isolation have been shown, MAC is the most commonly isolated pathogenic SGM, but numerous other SGM species also cause disease. In the United States,M. kansasii is the second most frequent pathogenic SGM species recovered from pulmonary specimens (16).

In recent years, hospital environmental contamination and acquired infections byM. intracellulare subsp. chimaera (previously M. chimaera) following cardiac bypass surgery have been recognized as a public health crisis. Reports from Europe and the United States have linked this species to contaminated heater-cooler devices used during surgery for extracorporeal circulation as part of cardiopulmonary bypass (18, 19). Although contaminated water within the units did not directly contact a patient’s blood, a cooling fan for the motor within the unit aerosolized organisms in water, which were dispersed from the machine into the sterile surgical field. Since 2013, over 120 cases of M. intracellulare subsp. chimaera infection have been linked to contaminated heater-cooler units globally with a 50% case fatality rate, though modeling suggests this incidence may be greatly underreported, and new cases continue to be recognized (20). Infection typically manifests 1 to 4 years after surgery as prosthetic valve endocarditis, vascular graft infection, or disseminated disease with mycobacteremia (21).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: Because of the presence of SGM species in the environment and their opportunistic pathogenic nature, determination of the clinical significance of SGM isolates in patient specimens is based upon multiple factors, including clinical setting, host-specific factors, species, the pathogenic potential of the organism, the number of positive cultures, the source of the culture isolate, and quantitation of organisms detected by smear and culture (16). For example, although the incidence of a specific SGM such as M. gordonae in sputum cultures is high, the pathogenicity of this species is very low. In contrast, SGM species causing respiratory disease, such as MAC and M. kansasii, and species associated with cutaneous disease, such as M. haemophilum, M. marinum, and M. ulcerans, are usually clinically significant pathogens. Our understanding of the clinical significance of newly described SGM will expand as more reports are published describing the clinical features associated with these infections. Table 2 provides information regarding laboratory features and clinical manifestations of the major clinically significant SGM.

The most commonly isolated pathogenic SGM are MAC species and subspecies. MAC members (especiallyM. avium and M. intracellulare) often cause chronic respiratory disease, and the classically associated hosts are middle-aged male smokers and postmenopausal females with bronchiectasis (“Lady Windermere syndrome”). In addition, the majority of NTM pulmonary infections in patients with cystic fibrosis are caused by MAC. Other presentations include lymphadenitis (usually unilateral), tenosynovitis, and disseminated disease, the latter particularly in persons with advanced HIV infection. It should be noted that MAC members are environmental organisms that are frequently found in drinking water, soil, plants, and animal sources. They can be commensals in pulmonary specimens, and therefore, determining the significance of isolates from respiratory sources requires clinical correlation. The Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) and American Thoracic Society (ATS) provide guidance on methods to assist with determining the significance of MAC members isolated from respiratory sources (16).

M. genavense is a fastidious SGM that requires supplementation of the medium with mycobactin J (an iron chelator) and extended incubation for up to 12 weeks for growth in culture. It is classically associated with immunocompromised hosts who have AIDS, although cases have been reported in persons with other immunocompromising conditions. It also causes disease in birds such as parrots and parakeets.

M. gordonae, the “tap water bacillus,” is one of the most commonly recovered mycobacteria in the laboratory but is often considered a contaminant or a nonpathogen. It is a scotochromogen found in soil and water sources and has only rarely been associated with disease in humans. Repeated isolation together with the appropriate clinical correlation is required to designate this species a pathogen. Therefore, routine susceptibility testing of M. gordonae isolates is not warranted (22).

M. haemophilum is a fastidious SGM that requires incubation at lower temperatures (28 to 30°C) and supplementation of the medium with iron-containing compounds, such as ferric ammonium citrate or hemin (X factor), for growth in culture. M. haemophilum is often isolated from immunocompromised hosts, particularly those with AIDS, and often presents as multiple skin nodules on the extremities. It is also recognized as a cause of cervical lymphadenopathy in otherwise healthy pediatric patients.

M. kansasii is often found in tap water and other water sources, and it causes chronic pulmonary disease that resembles tuberculosis. It can also cause skin and soft tissue infections, cervical lymphadenopathy, tenosynovitis, pericarditis, and, rarely, disseminated disease, typically in an immunocompromised host. M. kansasii is a photochromogenic species which has a 16S rRNA gene sequence that is indistinguishable from that of the nonphotochromogen M. gastri (23).

M. marinum infection is colloquially referred to as “the fish tank Mycobacterium” because infections often occur following exposure of traumatized skin to fresh or salt water, such as that found in fish tanks or in coastal areas. The typical clinical presentation is a single papulonodular lesion usually limited to an extremity (finger, elbow, foot, knee, etc.) that typically appears 2 to 3 weeks after inoculation and may become ulcerated with time. The infection may spread along the lymphatic system, resembling cutaneous sporotrichosis. Severe complications can include tenosynovitis, osteomyelitis, and disseminated infections. M. marinum is a photochromogen and requires incubation at lower temperatures (28 to 30°C) for optimal growth in microbiologic culture.

M. simiae is another SGM associated with chronic respiratory disease. Because of its resistance to most of the first-line tuberculous agents including rifabutin, it is often extremely difficult to treat and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality.

M. terrae complex has traditionally been considered an environmental commensal SGM. However, with the advent of molecular technology, several members of the complex, including M. arupense, M. kumamotonense, M. heraklionense, and M. virginiense, have been recognized as pathogens when associated with tenosynovitis or osteomyelitis. In contrast, species within the complex that were once considered pathogenic prior to the era of molecular identification, including M. terrae and M. nonchromogenicum, are now known to be only rarely pathogenic (24).

M. ulcerans is the third most common cause of mycobacterial disease worldwide following that caused by MTBC and M. leprae. M. ulcerans infection is referred to as Buruli ulcer in Africa and as Bairnsdale ulcer in Australia. The infection begins as a painless nodule or lump following traumatic implantation of the organism, often into an extremity (foot, leg, hand, etc.). Over time, the nodule begins to ulcerate, and eventually widespread ulcerative necrosis or osteomyelitis causes pain, disfigurement, and possibly loss of the affected limb. The tissue damage caused by M. ulcerans has been attributed to the production of the toxin mycolactone (25). M. ulcerans is difficult to grow in mycobacterial culture due to its fastidious nature. It prefers lower temperatures (28 to 30°C) and requires extended culture incubation of up to 3 months for recovery. Molecular techniques have been developed which may allow improved detection of this fastidious SGM (26).

M. xenopi was first isolated in 1957 from skin lesions on the African toad (Xenopus laevis), but it is now recognized as a human pathogen causing chronic respiratory disease, skin and soft tissue infections, septic arthritis, and disseminated disease primarily in the immunocompromised host. M. xenopi prefers to grow at higher temperatures (~45°C), and it has frequently been isolated from hot water systems and tanks.

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: One of the first, easiest, and least expensive means of detecting the presence of mycobacteria in clinical samples is microscopic examination. Acid-fast stains, along with the use of bright-field and fluorescence microscopy, are needed for staining these organisms, since routine Gram staining will not reliably detect mycobacteria due to their hydrophobic cell wall, which prevents stain penetration. Further discussion of specific staining techniques can be found inchapter 30.

sect1.title: Detection of Antigen, Antibody, and Interferon Gamma
sect1.para: Antigen detection is not performed for the direct detection of SGM in diagnostic laboratories. There are no commercially available immunodiagnostic tests for SGM species at this time; however,M. kansasii, M. marinum, and M. szulgai may nonspecifically cross-react with interferon gamma release assays used for the serologic diagnosis of latent tuberculosis infection (27).

sect1.title: Direct Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Direct detection of nucleic acid in clinical specimens by PCR methods has been reported for selected species, such as MAC andM. ulcerans. However, their current status as laboratory-developed tests rather than commercialized assays generally limits their use to research or public health laboratories rather than clinical diagnostic laboratories (26, 28). These assays often amplify regions within the 16S rRNA gene, the 16S-23S internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region, or the heat shock protein 65 gene (hsp65). The AnyPlex MTB/NTM real-time detection assay (Seegene, Seoul, South Korea) is a commercial multiplex real-time PCR assay that uses a proprietary technology that enables simultaneous screening and detection of multiple targets using a single fluorescent channel. This technology has been used for discrimination between NTM and MTBC directly from clinical specimens and recently demonstrated 100% sensitivity and 97% specificity in detection of NTM versus culture from 110 primarily respiratory clinical specimens; however, this assay is not currently available in the United States (29). A line probe assay, the GenoType CMdirect (Bruker-Hain Lifescience, Nehren, Germany), allows detection of MTBC and 20 clinically relevant NTM species from decontaminated sputum specimens.

sect1.title: M. leprae PCR
sect1.para: AsM. leprae is a nonculturable organism, PCR techniques have been developed and applied for its detection from a variety of specimen sources, such as slit-skin smears, blood, nasal cavity, biopsy specimens, and urine (30). Molecular targets for detection of M. leprae by PCR have included genes encoding the 18-kDa and 36-kDa protein antigens (known as the proline-rich antigen), genes encoding the 65-kDa and 85-kDa antigens, the 16S rRNA gene, and repetitive sequences (30, 31). Many studies have shown that PCR methods are specific and more sensitive than conventional methods (split-skin smears, histopathology, and serology) for the diagnosis of M. leprae and can be used to differentiate related species such as the nonvalidated “M. lepromatosis” (30, 32).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: The rapid detection and identification of NTM are an important task for a clinical mycobacteriology laboratory. Within the last few decades, the number of currently validated NTM species has increased from 30 to approximately 190 based on advances in identification by genetic sequencing versus traditional biochemical and morphological characteristics. This development has been paralleled by an increasing incidence of infections due to NTM.

Historically,Mycobacterium species identification has relied, with few exceptions, on the analysis of a series of phenotypic tests, whose performance was mostly restricted to specialized laboratories. These tests require a sufficient number of bacterial cells and several weeks of incubation. It is now recognized that most mycobacterial species cannot be reliably identified by biochemical and phenotypic tests and that definitive identification requires molecular analysis. Some species may exhibit convergent characteristics, and strains of one species may show variability in certain phenotypic features. In addition, many new species identified genetically have not been studied in detail by biochemical and phenotypic methods. DNA hybridization probes for the identification of selected SGM species including MAC (M. avium and M. intracellulare), M. gordonae, and M. kansasii grown on culture media have been available for many years; however, the manufacturer has indicated that it will discontinue these probes at the end of the 2022 calendar year.

The most reliable methods for identification of all mycobacterial species today involve molecular analyses of selected genes. These techniques have the additional advantage that they can be performed from liquid culture media, which generally enable more rapid growth and a more sensitive detection of mycobacteria than solid culture media. Mixed cultures with NTM are not uncommon (33), and thus, there is a risk associated in working solely with broth cultures. Therefore, all results obtained by molecular methods should be confirmed by correlation with phenotypic characteristics, such as growth rate, colony morphology, and pigmentation (Table 2), and by confirmation of the purity of the NTM isolate on solid medium. Reporting of molecular results should not be delayed for the phenotypic correlation and purity confirmation, but any genotype or phenotype discrepancies should be investigated and a revised report issued as necessary.

Not all laboratories may have the necessary funds, facilities, or instrumentation to provide molecular testing in mycobacteriology. If molecular identification techniques are not available, laboratories should refer SGM isolates to a reference laboratory with DNA sequencing or matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) capabilities for accurate identification (23).

sect1.title: Phenotypic Methods
sect1.para: Current guidelines recommend the use of both broth and solid media for the culture of mycobacteria. While liquid media (usually Middlebrook 7H9 or 7H12) allow rapid detection of mycobacterial growth, phenotypic evaluation of morphology requires that mycobacteria be grown on solid egg- or agar-based culture media. The rapid growth and subsequent molecular or MALDI-TOF MS identification of mycobacteria in liquid broth are generally sufficient for definitive species identification, although, as discussed above, care must be taken to ensure that the broth culture contains a single organism and is not a mixed culture. Therefore, the major application of phenotype-based analyses is to complement or support molecular identification, which may not always be unambiguous.

The key characteristics for the phenotypic classification of mycobacteria are growth rate, optimal growth temperature, colony morphology, and pigmentation. Biochemical tests have been largely discontinued, and their application in the modern mycobacteriology laboratory has become obsolete.

sect2.title: Growth Rate
sect2.para: Mycobacterial growth rate is an obvious property that is dependent on temperature, the initial bacterial inoculum, and the species. The estimation of growth rate is most reliably performed on solid media, even though protocols using standardized growth curves have been developed for growth in liquid media using the BACTEC MGIT (Becton Dickinson and Company, Franklin Lakes, NJ) and VersaTREK systems (Thermo Scientific/Trek Diagnostic Systems, Oakwood Village, OH). To perform a standardized growth test, defined suspensions of mycobacteria (e.g., equivalent to 0.5 McFarland) are inoculated on solid media and incubated at 30 ± 1°C and 36 ± 1°C. Cultures are observed for growth at 5 to 7 days and weekly thereafter. Mycobacteria can thus be classified into distinct groups of slowly and rapidly growing species. RGM form mature colonies on subculture within 7 days of incubation, whereas SGM require a longer incubation period for colony formation.

sect2.title: Temperature
sect2.para: Mycobacterium species differ in their ability to grow at certain temperatures. For determination of the preferred growth temperature, solid culture media are inoculated with defined suspensions of mycobacteria (e.g., 0.5 McFarland) and incubated at temperatures of 30 ± 1°C and 36 ± 1°C. Most SGM grow well at 35 to 37°C, but others, including M. marinum, grow better at a lower temperature (30°C), especially on primary isolation. Therefore, samples from skin, lymph nodes, and other tissue specimens from peripheral body sites should routinely be incubated at both 30 ± 1°C and 36 ± 1°C when specimen volume permits. Additional medium (e.g., with X factor for M. haemophilum) and incubation at lower or higher temperatures may be necessary for optimal growth of some species, such as M. haemophilum (28 to 32°C), M. xenopi (42°C), M. conspicuum (22 to 31°C), and M. stomatepiae (22°C). Cultures to determine temperature requirements of known RGM can generally be read within 1 week, while SGM require a longer period of incubation.

sect2.title: Colony Morphology
sect2.para: Colony morphology is a phenotypic property of mycobacteria that can easily be determined. Morphologic characteristics such as size and colony description (flat, raised, etc.) should be noted, but the most discriminating and relevant characteristic is the smooth or rough texture of the colonies. The colony morphology may vary when different formulations of solid media are used. Individual SGM species may exhibit either rough or smooth variants, so colony morphology alone is not a reliable parameter for their discrimination. Studies have suggested that the colony texture among the RGM may be related to pathogenicity, with rough colony morphology representing a more invasive phenotype, and a recent publication indicates this is also true for MAC (34).

sect2.title: Pigmentation and Photoreactivity
sect2.para: Pigmentation of mycobacteria has been used for primary classification into nonchromogenic and chromogenic species (Runyon classification system). NTM species can be chromogenic (scoto- or photochromogenic) or nonchromogenic. Chromogenic NTM species produce pigment that can range from light yellow to orange, or even rose-colored. Within the pigmented mycobacteria, the photochromogens are nonpigmented in the dark and produce pigmentation only after exposure to light (Fig. 1). Since pigment production is an oxygen-dependent reaction, primary cultures of these species may remain nonpigmented even when exposed to light if the culture tube caps are tightly closed. Loosening of the caps, done in a biological safety cabinet, helps to promote the color change. The scotochromogens produce pigment equally when grown in the dark and when exposed to light (Fig. 2). The color may intensify with the increasing age of the culture. The nonchromogenic species do not produce pigmentation under any lighting conditions. The color of nonchromogenic colonies may remain off-white, buff, or pale yellow and does not intensify when colonies are exposed to light (Fig. 3).

sect1.title: Identification of SGM
sect1.para: Phenotypic identification of SGM is no longer sufficient for species-level identification, and therefore, molecular methods have become the gold standard. Laboratory-specific capabilities, including facilities, technical expertise, and staffing levels, play an important role in selecting the appropriate molecular method. Laboratories without sufficient expertise should refer mycobacteria to a reference laboratory. It is also important to recognize that an unidentified mycobacterial isolate should be treated as if it isM. tuberculosis and that appropriate safety measures, including biosafety level 3 (BSL3) practices and facilities, should be used until M. tuberculosis is ruled out. The methods generally used in clinical laboratories for the identification of mycobacteria are described below, with the most common methods currently being nucleic acid hybridization with the AccuProbe probes, MALDI-TOF MS, and DNA sequencing of either the 16S, rpoB, or hsp65 target. As whole-genome sequencing (WGS) capabilities continue to mature, the utilization of this method of identification is also likely to increase.

sect2.title: MASS-SPECTROMETRIC IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: MALDI-TOF MS has revolutionized the identification of microorganisms, including mycobacteria. MALDI-TOF MS analysis of mycobacteria involves several steps, including inactivation, extraction, and analysis. Several different methods have been described for the inactivation and extraction of mycobacterial cells. Since there are additional safety concerns due to the potential for growth of MTBC when acid-fast-bacillus (AFB)-positive cultures are processed, these methods differ from extraction methods described for other bacteria and fungi. All inactivation and extraction steps should be performed within a BSL3 facility using the appropriate personal protective equipment untilM. tuberculosis complex has been ruled out. Additional information about biosafety issues associated with MALDI-TOF MS analysis of mycobacteria can be found in chapter 31.

MALDI-TOF MS analysis for both whole-cell (35) and purified protein extraction (36, 37) methods has been described. Inactivation and extraction of mycobacterial cells are more challenging than for other bacteria or yeasts and are typically achieved either by ethanol or heat treatment and mechanical dissociation or lysis of cells using either a micropestle or bead-beating techniques. Extraction is performed by adding formic acid and acetonitrile to the inactivated mycobacterial cells (36). Following inactivation and extraction, an aliquot is spotted onto a solid target support plate and overlaid with a chemical matrix (for example, alpha-cyano-4-hydroxy-cinnamic acid). MALDI-TOF MS is then performed as described in chapter 6. Currently, there are two commercial MALDI-TOF MS platforms available for microbial identification, the Vitek MS (bioMérieux, Durham, NC) and the Biotyper system (Bruker Daltonics, Billerica, MA) (35–38). Databases supplied with both instruments contain entries for MTBC and many NTM, including those most commonly encountered in the clinical laboratory. The species included in each commercial library at the time of this writing are included in Table 1. MALDI-TOF MS databases continue to improve in terms of species coverage and the depth of strain diversity, but more esoteric species may be underrepresented and may need to be added by the end user or await future database updates by the manufacturers. Like sequencing databases, MALDI-TOF MS databases need to be carefully evaluated for accuracy, especially with newly described species.

Recent studies have demonstrated the ability of MALDI-TOF MS to serve as a rapid and accurate means for the identification of mycobacteria from solid medium. The ability to directly identify NTM from positive cultures in liquid medium is reportedly variable (35–37, 39). Saleeb et al. (36) reported the identification of 104 mycobacterial isolates comprising 17 species by MALDI-TOF MS. Others have also demonstrated that MALDI-TOF MS can unambiguously identify some of the most commonly encountered species of SGM (38, 40). However, M. intracellulare and other members of the MAC may not be reliably differentiated based on current studies (35, 41). Differentiating members of the M. terrae complex by MALDI-TOF MS may also be challenging (38).

A potential pitfall of the identification by MALDI-TOF MS in comparison to molecular sequencing methods is the requirement for a moderate amount of growth present on solid media rather than scant growth required for sequencing. Not surprisingly, this problem is most evident when dealing with the SGM (38). Under such circumstances, sequencing may provide a more rapid turnaround time (i.e., 12 to 24 h) for identification than MALDI-TOF MS analysis and may be required when definitive identification is not achieved by MALDI-TOF MS.

sect1.title: Complete Genome Sequences
sect1.para: Complete genomic sequences have been established for many mycobacterial species. Detailed information on all genome projects either completed or still in progress can be obtained athttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/microbes/. A publication by Tortoli et al. suggests that the whole-genome sequence should be required for the description of each new mycobacterial species (42).

sect1.title: Single-Gene or 16S-23S rRNA Gene Spacer Region Analyses
sect1.para: Partial sequence analysis of selected genes or sequencing of the ITS 1 region between the 16S and 23S rRNA genes is the most practical method for identification of mycobacterial species. The sequencing of specific regions within the 16S rRNA gene,hsp65, rpoB, and the ITS 1 region has been commonly used to identify SGM species, as detailed below (43–45).

sect2.title: 16S rRNA Gene
sect2.para: For routine identification of mycobacteria, sequence analysis of the complete 16S rRNA gene (approximately 1,500 bp) is not practical and is usually not necessary. Sequencing a region of approximately 500 bp located near the 5′ end of the gene is typically sufficient for species identification. Specific primers for amplification and sequencing of the mycobacterial 16S rRNA gene (Table 3) have been described and verified, and a test kit is commercially available, though it is not FDA cleared (46, 47).

The 16S rRNA gene contains conserved and variable sequence regions that enable the definitive species identification of most SGM. A few SGM have identical hypervariable regions A and B or an identical complete 16S rRNA gene sequence. These include some of the species or subspecies within the MAC, the speciesM. marinum and M. ulcerans, and two species of M. kansasii complex (i.e., M. kansasii and “M. ostraviense” [not validly published at this time; former subspecies IV]) with M. gastri. For accurate identification of these species, sequence analysis of other genes or regions (e.g., the ITS, hsp65, or rpoB) is required. In addition, some SGM have minor intraspecies 16S rRNA gene sequence variants which differ by a few base pairs (e.g., M. gordonae and M. lentiflavum) (9, 48, 49).

Pyrosequencing of a portion of the 16S rRNA gene has also been used for the identification of mycobacteria. Identification of mycobacteria by pyrosequencing relies on a 20- to 30-bp region within hypervariable region A of the 16S rRNA gene (50, 51). A study evaluating pyrosequencing for the analysis of AFB isolates was performed by Bao et al. (51) in comparison to phenotypic analysis and Sanger sequencing. Pyrosequencing identified 114 of the 117 (98%) AFB isolates and correctly identified most of the SGM to the species level (51). Of the mycobacteria tested, it was not able to identify M. scrofulaceum and M. simiae to the species level. Similar to Sanger sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene, pyrosequencing has limitations for identification of some closely related organisms. Pyrosequencing has the advantage of being a rapid, simple, and inexpensive molecular method for identification of Mycobacterium species. Additional sequencing may be required to differentiate some species due to the short sequence length generated by this technique.

sect2.title: ITS 1 Region
sect2.para: The ITS sequence separates the 16S and 23S rRNA genes in the operon and is designated ITS 1. The sequence of this fragment comprises only 200 to 330 bp and thus can easily be analyzed. Several sets of primers that enable the amplification and sequencing of the complete fragment are published (Table 3) (9, 52).

The high sequence variability within ITS 1 among species has been targeted for SGM differentiation (53). However, for some species of SGM (M. simiae and M. xenopi), two or more sequence variants have been observed within ITS 1. M. marinum and M. ulcerans have identical ITS 1 sequence and thus cannot be differentiated by targeting this genetic region. The ITS region is also useful for differentiation of M. szulgai and M. angelicum as well as the species of the M. kansasii complex.

sect2.title: hsp65 Gene
sect2.para: One of the first genetic targets used for the differentiation of mycobacteria is a 441-bp fragment at the 5′ end of the ofhsp65 gene, which encodes the 65-kDa heat shock protein and is also known as the groEL2 gene. Advantages of sequencing the partial hsp65 gene rather than the 16S rRNA gene are especially evident in the identification of closely related species, as hsp65 is much less conserved than the 16S rRNA gene. hsp65 gene sequencing allows differentiation of M. marinum from M. ulcerans and M. gastri from M. kansasii complex. M. avium subsp. avium, M. avium subsp. paratuberculosis, and “M. avium subsp. hominissuis” (nonvalidated species) can be distinguished from each other with sequencing of the 3′ end (54–56).

sect2.title: rpoB Gene
sect2.para: TherpoB gene encodes the β subunit of the bacterial RNA polymerase. For NTM species, sequence variability within rpoB can be used for species identification (43, 57). Several different sequence fragments of the approximately 3,600-bp gene have been used for amplification and sequence determination. Kim et al. (58) amplified a fragment comprising 306 bp at positions 1362 to 1668 (referred to as region 2/3), whereas Lee et al. (57) targeted a 360-bp sequence at positions 902 to 1261 (referred to as region 1/2). In contrast, Adékambi et al. (43) chose a more distant fragment (region 5) and analyzed an approximately 760-bp fragment at positions 2573 to 3337 (Table 3). In the studies by Kim et al., and Lee et al., type strains of some SGM were included; however, detailed analyses using region 5 demonstrated that it was superior to the other regions for RGM and M. avium differentiation (43, 59). The rpoB gene is also useful for the differentiation of M. marinum from M. ulcerans, M. kansasii complex from M. gastri, and M. szulgai from M. angelicum.

sect1.title: Use of Sequence Databases
sect1.para: For identification of mycobacteria by sequencing analysis, public databases are frequently used, which can present challenges. Public databases may contain sequences from strains which are not validly published as species, sequences from strains identified as known species but having divergent sequences, and many sequences from uncultured bacteria which are not further characterized. Furthermore, old sequences that are fragmentary, are inaccurate, or use incorrect taxonomy may still be included in public databases (60). The NCBI Reference Sequence (RefSeq) database is a public, curated reference database which contains many well-annotated Mycobacterium species genomes (61).

Thus, search results must be evaluated with care. For example, in the case of an uncommon species, the designation can easily be checked as a species with a validly published name by using the public database “List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature” (http://www.bacterio.net), maintained by Leibniz Institute DSMZ as of 2019 (6). When several results derived from different species are obtained, it may help to check the database entries to determine if the sequences have been obtained from type strains. Other resources listing officially validated species include this Manual and the International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology.

The International Nucleotide Sequence Database Collaboration (INSDC) database (http://www.insdc.org/) can be used for the analysis of the sequences derived from the different genes as detailed above. There are some curated databases and analysis tools that have been constructed for the analysis of 16S rRNA gene sequences, such as the commercially available tools SmartGene IDNS (SmartGene, Lausanne, Switzerland), RipSeq (Pathogenomix, Santa Cruz, CA), and MicroSeq microbial identification system (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA). Two online tools with free access include the Ribosomal Database Project (http://rdp.cme.msu.edu/) and the EzBioCloud (www.ezbiocloud.net). The advantages of these databases are the improved quality control and curation of the entries, as opposed to truly public databases that do not restrict submissions. For the commercial Web-based databases, the user also has the option to update the system as needed. However, these curated databases can lag behind the updates of the INSDC database and may not include sequence variants of species.

sect2.title: OTHER MOLECULAR TESTS FOR NTM
sect2.para: Sequence analysis of target genes for the identification of mycobacteria is not practical for routine use in most clinical laboratories. Commercially available assays that are based on liquid- or solid-phase hybridization have been shown to be easily implemented into a routine workflow. They are intended for the detection of some of the more clinically relevantMycobacterium species and can be performed from both solid and liquid media.

sect1.title: AccuProbe Culture Identification Tests
sect1.para: The AccuProbe test (Hologic/GenProbe, Marlborough, MA) was the first commercial molecular assay for the identification of selected mycobacterial species from positive culture media, and the probes have been widely used for the identification of SGM. However, these probes will be discontinued by the manufacturer late in the calendar year 2022. Probes are available for the identification of MTBC,M. avium, M. intracellulare, MAC, M. gordonae, and M. kansasii. Species identification is based on the hybridization of specific DNA probes to rRNA of the bacteria. Briefly, by heat treatment and sonication, nucleic acids, including the target 16S rRNA, are released from the mycobacteria. A DNA probe specifically hybridizes with the target rRNA. Finally, the DNA-rRNA hybrid molecule is detected by chemiluminescence. The results can be obtained within 2 h. The utility of these tests has been documented in many studies from laboratories worldwide (9, 62, 63).

sect1.title: Line Probe Assays
sect1.para: Alternatively, techniques based on the application of PCR plus reverse hybridization-designed DNA strip assays (line probe assays) have been developed. Briefly, the target sequences are amplified by PCR using biotinylated primers. The amplified PCR products hybridize to immobilized, membrane-bound probes covering the species-specific sequence fragment, followed by an enzyme-mediated color reaction. The banding patterns are analyzed visually by comparing the patterns on an interpretation chart. The identification of the species relies on specific banding patterns (Fig. 4).

sect1.para: Three tests for the identification of several mycobacterial species are commercially available; they are CE marked but are not FDA cleared. The INNO-LiPA Mycobacteria v2 assay (Fujirebio, Ghent, Belgium) is based on the nucleotide differences in the 16S-23S rRNA gene spacer region and can detect the MTBC and the following other SGM species:M. kansasii, M. xenopi, M. gordonae, M. genavense, M. simiae, M. marinum, M. ulcerans, M. celatum, M. avium-M. intracellulare-M. scrofulaceum complex (MAIS), M. avium, M. intracellulare, M. scrofulaceum, M. malmoense, and M. haemophilum.

The GenoType Mycobacterium CM/AS test (Hain Lifescience, Nehren, Germany) is based on the detection of species-specific sequences in the 23S rRNA gene. It is composed of two different strips (strip CM is for common mycobacteria, and strip AS is for additional species) and can identify MTBC and the following other slowly growing mycobacteria: with strip CM,M. avium, M. gordonae, M. intracellulare/M. intracellulare subsp. chimaera, M. scrofulaceum/M. paraffinicum/M. parascrofulaceum, M. interjectum, M. kansasii, M. malmoense/M. haemophilum/M. palustre/M. nebraskense, M. marinum/M. ulcerans, and M. xenopi; and with strip AS, M. simiae, M. celatum (types 1 and 3), M. genavense/M. triplex, M. lentiflavum, M. heckeshornense, M. szulgai/M. intermedium, M. haemophilum/M. nebraskense, M. kansasii, M. ulcerans, M. gastri, M. asiaticum, and M. shimoidei (species separated by a slash have the same banding pattern). The Hain GenoType NTM-DR line probe assay allows detection of several NTM species and resistance markers for the aminoglycosides and macrolides.

Both the Fujirebio and Hain Lifesciences tests can be conducted on isolates grown from liquid or solid culture media, and the results are available in approximately 4 to 6 h. Several studies have evaluated the utility of these tests. Concordant results of 89.9 to 98.6% for the GenoType CM and AS assays with sequencing-based methods have been reported (10, 64). Most (up to 96%) of the regularly encountered species can be identified using the GenoType CM assay alone (10). A limitation of this test is the resolution of patterns that are shared by more than one species, which necessitates additional techniques for further discrimination (e.g., sequencing of additional gene targets or biochemical tests), leading to a delay in obtaining a final result. For the INNO-LiPA assay, 92.2 to 98.4% concordant results with standard methods have been reported (65, 66). The assay can further differentiate M. kansasii and M. chelonae strains into subtypes.

A third line probe assay, the Speed-oligo Mycobacteria (Vircell, Granada, Spain), is based on targeting both 16S rRNA and 16S-23S rRNA regions. The assay can detect several mycobacterial species, including MTBC (M. tuberculosis, M. bovis, M. microti, M. africanum, and M. caprae) and NTM (M. avium, M. gordonae, M. interjectum, M. intracellulare, M. kansasii, M. malmoense, M. marinum/M. ulcerans, M. scrofulaceum, and M. xenopi). The Speed-oligo Mycobacteria has a limited spectrum of species identifications compared to the other assays and identifies many of the mycobacterial species to the complex or group level. It can be performed on isolates from solid or liquid media within 3 h. Clinically relevant misidentifications reported to date include the identification of M. marinum as M. kansasii, M. kansasii as MTBC, and single isolates of M. chelonae and M. peregrinum as M. abscessus. The Speed-oligo Mycobacteria has also been evaluated for use directly from respiratory specimens and demonstrated an overall sensitivity of 76% (93% from smear-positive specimens and 56% from smear-negative specimens) and specificity of 99%. The study concluded that the assay is an easy and fast alternative for detecting mycobacteria and differentiating between MTBC and NTM, especially from smear-positive specimens (67).

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Historically, the first strain typing method forM. avium was serotyping based on seroagglutination procedures. The combined use of serotyping and species-specific DNA probes has shown that previously named serovars 1 through 6 and 8 through 11 are M. avium and that serovars 7, 12 through 17, 19, 20, and 25 are M. intracellulare. Serotyping, for both MAC and other mycobacteria, has been replaced by molecular strain typing. Different genetic approaches have been used for strain comparisons of NTM. Analyses have included pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) (68, 69), amplified fragment length polymorphism analysis (70), and restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) typing using specific molecular markers (71). For PFGE and amplified fragment length polymorphism analysis, no genetic information is necessary, and the procedures can be performed without further knowledge of the species genome. For RFLP typing, some genetic information, such as the presence of specific IS elements, is a prerequisite. Older typing systems, such as PFGE and RFLP, are gradually being replaced by WGS, but at the time of this writing, these methods are still in use in some laboratories.

sect1.title: Pulsed-Field Gel Electrophoresis
sect1.para: PFGE has been a useful technique for strain typing of the SGM. This technique requires an actively growing culture and takes 3 to 4 weeks to complete. Problems with standardization may result from cell clumping of rough strains. This clumping may also result in different amounts of DNA from separate batches of the same strain, causing uneven (light or overloaded) lanes that are difficult to interpret. Previous studies have detailed the method of PFGE related to clinical and epidemiologic studies ofM. kansasii, M. szulgai, and MAC (72–74). PFGE has been applied to study macrolide-susceptible and -resistant isolates and multiple cultures of patients with nodular MAC disease and bronchiectasis (73). A major importance of this method is the differentiation of “new infections” versus “relapse infections” (75).

sect1.title: Multilocus Sequence Typing
sect1.para: Another approach for NTM typing is analysis of multiple genes with a high sequence variation, like thehsp65 gene or the ITS region. However, available sequence polymorphisms have not provided the level of variability needed for epidemiological analyses. With the progress of whole-genome analysis, however, multilocus sequence typing may prove increasingly useful for typing of NTM.

sect1.title: VNTR Analysis
sect1.para: The analysis of variable-number tandem repeats (VNTRs) of mycobacterial interspersed repetitive units was initially applied to typing ofM. avium subsp. paratuberculosis (MAP) strains but now has been expanded to other members of the MAC (76). Although the VNTR loci are usually species specific, the low cost, reproducibility, smaller volume of DNA required, and speed of the VNTR technique suggest that it could be a substitute method for PFGE strain comparison for MAC and M. kansasii isolates (77, 78). Additionally, two recent studies used VNTR analysis and WGS to show that patients with M. avium had isolates that were genetically matched to household water (79, 80).

sect1.title: IS1245 and IS900 RFLP Analysis
sect1.para: The most extensive investigations for typing of NTM strains have been undertaken forM. avium. RFLP analysis based on the insertion sequence IS1245, which is restricted to M. avium, has been used for genotyping. Standardization of this technique was proposed in 1998 (81), but this technology never became widespread. However, Mijs et al. (82) used this method as one tool for distinguishing M. avium subsp. avium strains obtained from bird specimens from swine- and human-derived strains, for which they proposed the name “M. avium subsp. hominissuis.” RFLP analysis based on the insertion sequence IS900 can be used for genotyping of MAP. The availability of the complete genome sequences of the “M. avium subsp. hominissuis” strain 104 and the MAP strain K-10 made it possible to search for divergent regions that can be used for standardization of other techniques for genotyping (71). Based on the genomic sequence data, large-sequence polymorphisms were identified that varied among different M. avium strains. Multilocus sequence typing now allows many genes that contain multiple sequence variations to be analyzed in parallel (56).

sect1.title: WGS
sect1.para: To date, the use of WGS of NTM has been limited in the clinical laboratory, and it is most often used as a research tool for taxonomic work and investigation of outbreaks. One major use of WGS has been the analysis of genetic differences among the NTM to aid in taxonomic identification and to clarify subspecies and species level taxonomy (2, 42). A 2020 U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) study of the genetic diversity among subspecies of M. avium compared the genomes of M. avium subsp. paratuberculosis, M. avium subsp. avium and “M. avium subsp. hominissuis.” Interestingly, the research suggested that horizontal gene transfer, which has been hypothesized in several NTM species, did not occur in M. avium subsp. paratuberculosis but did occur in the other two subspecies of M. avium (83). Recent studies in Italy have also shown the utility of WGS in identification and genomic characterization, including investigation of mycobacterial virulence and antibiotic resistance determinants of multiple species of NTM. These studies also provided insight into the impact of horizontal gene transfer, which appears to be less important in several NTM species than originally thought (42, 84).

In addition, a study performed in Korea compared MAC genomes, with genetic distances estimated by single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), in three pairs of cohabiting patients, including a mother and daughter. Comparison of the MAC strains to a public database suggested that there was a low likelihood of patient-to-patient transmission in immunocompetent individuals (79).

One of the most important recent uses of the WGS was illustrated in a global outbreak ofM. intracellulare subsp. chimaera infections following cardiac surgeries. WGS provided vital evidence to associate bioaerosols produced by contaminated heater-cooler units (HCU) with the development of serious infection due to M. intracellulare subsp. chimaera. WGS of HCU-associated M. intracellulare subsp. chimaera from eight U.S. sites was compared to the sequencing of global isolates from Denmark, Australia, Italy, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and Switzerland, and the analysis further implicated a single-point source of contamination that resulted in worldwide dissemination of this SGM following surgery (85).

A lack of expertise in bioinformatics, which is necessary to analyze the data, and the expense of the instrumentation are problematic for the introduction of WGS into most clinical laboratories at this time. Moreover, current databases are often inadequate, and validation of results is difficult, but these challenges are anticipated to be overcome in time as the use of WGS in mycobacteriology expands.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITY TESTING
sect2.para: Antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) of clinically relevant mycobacteria is important for the treatment of infections caused by many mycobacterial species. AST should be performed using the reference broth dilution method when mycobacteria are recovered from a normally sterile body site or are otherwise considered clinically significant. Interpretive criteria and breakpoints have been established for MAC,M. kansasii, and for SGM other than MAC and M. kansasii by the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) (22). Antimicrobial susceptibility testing of mycobacteria can be technically challenging and should be performed only by experienced personnel. Specific details and discussion of the AST procedures can be found in chapter 79.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Implementation of sensitive and rapid methods for the detection, identification, and susceptibility testing of SGM is important for the diagnosis and control of disease. The use of the fluorochrome stain for mycobacterial smears, a broth-based culture system, and MALDI-TOF MS or sequence analysis for species identification are optimal for supporting the decisions required for patient care. AST of clinically significant species is frequently helpful to select antimicrobials for the effective treatment of patients with SGM infections. As emphasized in this chapter, phenotypic testing of the SGM species has extremely limited use and should be applied only in conjunction with molecular assays. Laboratory work should be organized to prioritize timely and accurate identification of SGM and susceptibility testing of clinically significant isolates. Results should be reported within 24 h for positive AFB smears and interim reports should be issued as soon as culture growth is seen on inoculated solid media or when a positive signal is detected from liquid media. The use of liquid media for rapid detection paired with solid medium for confirming purity and to maximize recovery of isolates that do not grow well in the broth medium is critical to meet these recommendations (16, 22). A confirmatory final report should be issued when species identification is completed. Moreover, reporting should also be done as soon as susceptibility testing is completed which is usually within about 14 days for SGM.

In an effort to develop a more consistent and practical method of reporting identifications performed by molecular techniques, the CLSI has published interpretive criteria for the identification of mycobacterial species by DNA target sequencing (23). The document provides guidance for the identification of mycobacteria to the species level using the 16S rRNA target and alternative targets such as ITS, rpoB, and hsp65. However, microheterogeneity within an NTM species (i.e., 1 to 5 bases in the 16S rRNA gene that are different from the sequence of a known reference strain) has been described for several SGM species, including M. gordonae, M. bohemicum, M. celatum, and M. lentiflavum. In general, members of the genus Mycobacterium are closely related to each other in their 16S rRNA gene sequences and may differ by only a few bases or not at all. In the absence of strong phenotypic differences, definitive identification using a single target may be difficult for some species and the use of multiple sequencing targets may be necessary.
